description.text:
Designed for a trench run the base is 40mm wide the same size as a large ship base. I am going to add one using a small ship base at some stage. But for the moment there are 2 versions here 1 very basic and 1 with a small bit of optical extra for cinematic purposes...

"I used to bullseye womp rats in my T-16 back home. They're not much bigger than two meters."

Converts four plastic bottles in a tank of water up to 8 liters. , The distance between the rings is 9 cm, compatible with all PET bottles. Above each ring there is a small tube that allows air to escape.

Both pegs are 5mm in diameter by about 7mm long. The edge of the top peg is 7.7mm (center 10.2mm) from the wall so it must an imperial measurement.

Used to help hold a flyscreen against a wall
Hole for 3mm screw.

Hi!

With the release of Arcadia Quest Inferno, the city has fallen into the Inferno and the demons are going around freely. The statue of the beloved king David III has been destroyed and the beautiful fountain corrupted with a new evil image.

And so, I designed this fountain to match the situation of the city. This is a scenery piece for the game Arcadia Quest Inferno (and the kickstarter campaign Fall of Arcadia). It is divided in various pieces so it is possible to vary the print quality (0.1mm recommended) in each one. Beacuse of this, glue is needed to ensure the stablity of the assembled model. Both the base and pillars are the same of the previous fountain so the new parts can be assembled in the old ones. Some parts may need to be repositioned in the slicer for optimice printing, depending on the software or printer used. Prints need support structures!

In terms of gameplay, you can use this in any scenario that uses the 20A tile, placing it in its central space. This space is Blocked by default, so no gameplay interruption!
This model is based in the concepts and artwork showed in the game Arcadia Quest Inferno, property of CoolMiniorNot and Spaghetti Western Games.

I hope you like it and I´ll be happy to read your feedback!

title: Customizable Car Vent Sunglass Holder v2.0

description.text:
Customizable Car Vent Sunglass Holder v2.0

This is an update to my first, original, customizable OpenSCAD design. This is Version 2.0 of the car vent sunglass holder with a ball and socket connector. It is very small and unobtrusive on your dash, but keeps the sunglasses handy. The original version is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1448661

The cool thing about this Thingy, is the printing of the ball in the socket all at once. There is just a little resistance to the ball turning when you first take it off the print bed. But, a little twist breaks it free and it turns nicely in the socket.

Version 2.0 adds wedges to the end of the "arms" of the Sunglass holder. Thanks for the idea DDD_guy. I've added two wedges and made it all parametric.

Printer:

Prusa I3 Rework 1.5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

Printed with ABS since it will be in the sun (albeit through glass) and stored in a hot car. Would probably be fine with PLA.

comments.text:
-Update-
I still love this case, but I ran into a deal breaker. I added a WIFI module to the 8 pin IDC header of the back of the MKS TFT32 module. The Z-height of the case does not permit the addition of this part. Furthermore, the mounting bracket is directly under this module so that cutting a relief hole is impossible.
comments.author: Rick_H

comments.text:
I made this, it is almost perfect. Only issue is that the indented relief is really tight requiring some filing to make both halve fit correctly. At first, I thought this was caused by my machine, but since I printed the top and bottom portions at the same locations on the printer bed and the outside dimensions have a delta of .15 mm, the problem is the tolerance is a bit too tight.
Besides the tolerance issue, the only improvement would be making the four screws blind on the top side for aesthetics.
In short this is a beautiful design and many thanks to the author. After my paint dries I will upload photos.

title: XYZ Printing daVinci Jr 1.0 - Stock Hotend Compact Mount with Silent/Quiet Part Cooling Fan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Only tested on RAMPS modified Jr but should work on stock firmware as well, just ensure you adjust Z offset.

This mount doesn't have place for hotend PCB, you'll need to relocate it if used with stock firmware.

Purpose of this design is:

  1. to use stock hotend
  2. to have silent/quiet fan therefore reduce overal noise of the machine
  3. no gap between "funnel" and the hotend (potentially to be able to do flexible filament printing, obviously extruder needs to be modified for flexibles so not tested yet)
  4. have a compact solution overall

You need 12v 50mm Radial Fan for this.
Also I'd suggest to get one of those hotend insulation cotton wraps of aliexpress and stick it between copper hotend head and printed part.
I did around 80h of printing so far with this mount and plastic underneath gone slightly shinier then the rest but isn't melted or so (printed in PLA btw)

If you look at the design for "cold end" cooling side - that cone there in the middle is for "cyclone effect" airflow to make cooling a bit more efficient and evenly distributed across the heatsink.

Also part cooling fan outlet is in angle so it doesn't hit hotend itself but only printed part.

XYZ Printing da Vinci Jr

description.text:
After being inspired by AnthongRedbeard's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14991 I went about designing my own Nerf mine.
The mine consists of two components, the top part holds 6 Nerf projectiles in a revolver cylinder arrangement with a central guiding hole. The base consist of a central guide that has a hole positioned for a retaining pin. Surrounding the guide are six ejection rods. Elastic bands are used to store the energy required to propel the projectiles just over 3 metres. My cylinder stopped printing about 75% through the print run but worked anyway so I haven't bothered reprinting it.

comments.text:
Cylinder Update! I have made a few updates to the Cylinder magazine. Download the MKIII Cylinder for improved functionality I have added a slot on one side that allows a strap/string/wire etc to be use to attach the mine to an appropriate object. Two ears have been added to the lower edge of the opposite side these have a hole in each which allows a safety pin to be added to reduce the possibility of unintentional discharge when setting the mine. Most importantly the height of the Cylinder has been reduced to ensure that the ejection rods completely clear the cylinder. this makes a slight improvement in the range of Nerf projectiles. (Picture and new STL added)
Thank you!
comments.author: IanGrayden

comments.text: Trigger Update! Looking into the trigger issue I stumbled on a solution used by William Mills. Basically I used a small strip cut from a tin can and bent up each in so that it clips over the side of the cylinder. On one of the ejection rods I used a hacksaw blade to cut a small notch into one of the ejection rods . To arm the mine the cylinder is moved to the set position and the clip is positioned over the side of the cylinder with the end of the strip fitted into the notch. The cylinder is drawn back onto the strip with the pressure from the bands holding it in place. I tied some fishing through a hole in the spring on the top end. Only slight tension on the line caused the clip to pull off the top of the cylinder triggering the mine. (Pictures added)

description.text:
holder for glue.Prusa i4
Printed nozzle 0.4 mm layer thickness: 0.2 mm Plastic PLA

This is a 6" Filament Guide for Ikea Lack Table Enclosures. I've seen plenty around, but I needed to make a custom one with larger side on top to cover up chips in the top of the table while putting the holes in.

I made sure to round both the edge coming into the top of the guide and also the bottom where the filament will be coming through. This was to help it slide more easily and not get caught on 90 degree edges.

Dimensions: (Part that slides into table)
L : 6"
W : 3/8"
H : Varies on STL used

L : 152.4mm
W : 9.1mm
H : Varies on STL

How To:

  • Draw a line 5 5/8" in length where you want the slit for Filament to be.
  • Drill a 3/8" hole on either side of the line (You will get 6" total length due to drill radius)
  • Now drill out the entire line.
  • Use whatever tool you find easiest to combine all the holes in to one slot 6" x 3/8"
  • Sand Edges smooth
  • Insert Filament Guide.

Files:
FilamentGuideSHORT - Allows you to put one on either side of the top piece to cover drill marks
FilamentGuideLONG - Allows you to use one piece to guide all the way through.

Would love to see your makes if you print one off!
Designed in AutoCAD - Exported to STL

This grinder was designed and made for a couple of reasons:

  1. I had just received my first purchase of m3 threaded inserts and wanted to give them a try.
  2. The herb that I just received was quite damp and did not play well with the toothless grinders that I had.

Things of note
If you do not wish to use m3 threaded inserts I have included copies of the files that do not require them.

If you have created http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2138128 you will already have a compatible Tray and Housing. I will try to continue this trend with future designs.

Requirements and Options

Required Parts
There are several combinations of parts that can be used to construct this grinder - Threaded, No Threads, m3x10 or m3x25. At minimum you must have the parts required for the Basic Config.

Maximum Overkill Config

  • 15 x m3x25 screws
  • 14 x m3x10 screws
  • 29 x m3 threaded inserts (H x OD: 3mm x 5mm)

Basic Config

  • 29 x m3x10 screws

You will need to print a Top, Grinding Plate, Housing and Tray. Their individual options will require the following parts to complete.

Top

  • 15 lots of m3x10 or m3x25 screws
  • Threaded or No Threads

Grinding Plate

  • 14 lots of m3x10 screws
  • Threaded or No Threads

Housing

  • Rifled, Knurled or Plain. These options are purely aesthetic but they will affect print time.

Tray
No options.

Photography

This is a quick prototype to try out an idea I had for a 3 DoF joint. It's very much a work in progress, so it currently doesn't do anything. Eventually, the arm needs to be designed to have cables attached to it to actuate it.

The benefits of this joints are that the string can go through a larger radius turn from horizontal to vertical, it should be pretty low friction once made out of better materials, and the range of motion is quite large. If the strings are angled down more, it could probably have a range of motion larger than 180 degrees in every direction.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PypkjQLSAy0

description.text:
Finally made a customisable version of the modular y carriage. My head getting more confused and dizzy when I make this and incorporating more modules inside especially the lm8uu mounts.

The beam's 2 screw holes are 10mm apart instead of the previous versions which was around 8-9mm apart from the center.

It is assumed that if you're going to use this customisable modular y carriage means you know the width of your 8mm smooth rod for your machine.

If you want to help me simplify this it would be greatly appreciated through the comment, I tried my best for this one.

Variable Explanation

I know there are tons of variables out there, but the most important ones are

  • dimX,dimY - based on the size of your heatbed
  • mountingOffsets - the offsets for screw mounting holes
  • tolerance - clearance to match your printer's accuracy
  • preview - preview or printable parts 0:1
  • view - the parts you want to be rendered
  • posX,posY - lm8uu mount attached to the corner parts
  • bearingz - lm8uu mounting heights if you're using the bearing on the beam
  • lm_beam - 0:1, if you want the lm8uu mounted on the beam or corner
  • modular_beam - If you want to have a single beam or modular
  • beam_corner - how much offset you want the beam to be from the edge, useful with lm_beam=1
  • Xbase, Ybase - These are the base position for the mounting at the outer edge of the corner module

I have designed a fischertechnik srew from one piece.
At 0.1 mm resolution, the game is the same as the original. At 0.2mm it is a little heavily because there is almost no game.
So that it can be printed without raft I have added a 20 gear.
Inside is a 4mm fischertechnik shaft. Without this, the screw is not stable.
The transition between the gear wheel and the screw is a fracture point. Caution when removing the pressure bed.
I have printed the snail up to 30cm. From 25 cm it became somewhat unclean by the movement of the nozzle.
A printer with a firm print bed is recommended.

The snail I have produced in the 30 mm grid. I have removed 3.5mm for a spacer ring. The should be on the gear side so that this can run freely.

Grid size:
120
160
200
240
300
Feedback and change requests are welcome.

This probably wont take too much abuse, but I wanted to design a brace for my Lunchbox. It's pretty strong, but thin and brittle. Maybe remix it?

Designed so it prints on it's side with no supports needed,

Recommend high infill for strength.

description.text: Many of the upgrades I designed for my Makerfarm Pegasus 10. Included are mounts for the RAMPS and bed relay. A redesigned Titan Extruder mount that includes a mount for the BLTouch as well as a mount for fans. I also found that getting rid of the bed springs has improved my prints dramatically, so I included my corner supports that work with a 4mm thick piece of glass. I also like the idea for a bearing support of the top of the Z axis, so I included my design for those as well. I mount my motors in the middle of Z axis rail (I replaced the X axis rails with 500mm rails), but also included a generic bearing support that should work on the left Z axis, you just have to measure and drill your own hole. They are made to fit a 8 x 22 x 7 bearing. As for the extruder I found it better to print the parts separately and then super glue them together.

description.text:

author: mikel0142

description.text:
In my Chess Clock project I wanted to create a switch that is hold down by a magnet (part of the micro solenoid), and released electronically.
For this I have design this set of parts around a cheep micro-solenoid.

  • The first piece will sit on the top of the solenoid. [Should be split before print, and glued together afterwards!] This piece will keep the lower end of the spring.
  • The second piece holds the T-bar, and the other end of the spring.
  • The third piece connects the second piece and the button, also acts as a bumper.
  • The forth piece is the button, that should be located outer the case.
  • The fifth piece should be glued to the case from the outer side. This will prevent dirt come in, but more importantly disables the button from being turned. I had 4mm face thickness in my box.
  • The sixth piece is a bonus piece, it is required to my clock project: this is a rotary encoder knob with the same design as the button before.

You will also need a spring. A spring from a ball-pen is unfortunately too hard, so I made mine out of a guitar string.
A piece of nail connect the external knob with the internal parts.

See details on: https://sharedinventions.com/?p=254
Featured video: https://youtu.be/8eZaJewicOY

description.text:
I am working on a project called the Air Quality Egg. Here is a Kickstarter video: http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/edborden/air-quality-egg We got funding in just 4 days! Okay, so here's the deal, we are a bunch of tinkerers and hackers, who really believe in open source communities. That is why Thingiverse is so awesome to our project. I have been mainly working with the physical prototype of the Air Quality Egg - a form that will hold electronic hardware that communicates with sensors outside your window, door, or wherever you place your sensors. Currently, this prototype is made to be 3D printed. There are special slots for magnets. However, we are investigating with options to create an injection mold. Currently, we have to make over 400 eggs! And the kickstarter isn't even over! I have some experience with casting, and know a lot of the aspects of this model is not good (undercuts, etc.). I will be tweaking this soon, but would LOVE to see what you guys come up with. Some things that I was thinking:
What are some clever connections besides magnets? Maybe threaded? Snaps? Other forms for the Egg? Does it have a flat bottom or something? Let us know your thoughts! There is more information about the process of the project, as well as STL and Rhino files of the digital model throughout different stages. Warning, earlier models are messy! http://airqualityegg.wikispaces.com/Industrial+design Okay, let's get down to it. Rhino files are on the wiki. If you need any other file types that I can export to, let me know: [email protected] Additional technical information:
The files are created with Rhino. The digital models are exported from watertight meshes. The two holes in the back is for an Ethernet cord and a power cord. There has been talk about using free software for modeling... I'd be interested!

If you print some Eggs, I'd love to see pictures! E-mail me at [email protected] or post it anywhere on our google group: http://groups.google.com/group/airqualityegg?pli=1 We will certainly post it everywhere we can!

A Tesla Turbine that uses 608 bearings and has a a modular shaft to attach any tool to. The 608 Skate bearing goes into the rotor housing, and then the rod goes into the hole in the skate bearing. This rod serves as the exhaust for the turbine and allows the air to go through the system. Do not plug the hole on the rod as it is important to the turbine. The rod has one end with a special connector I made for it so it can hook up to things such as a gear box. The intake for the turbine is located on the rotor housing, which is a 1cm diameter hole. All of these parts press fit together. I haven't measured the RPM this thing can reach, but it makes a pretty scary noise going full tilt.

Gears can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2502253

WARNING: Be careful with this when you are spinning it as it could break and send shards of plastic flying. Be sure to engage safety squints and also wear proper eye protection.

print_settings.Notes:: My printer isn't great so you may find the battery is a bit of a sloppy fit if done on a good printer.

description.text:
This is a battery holder (including clip) for Makita BL1013 10.8v batteries - the kind found in a whole range of Makita hand-held products.

Just print, get 2 thin spade connectors (or sheets of metal), glue them in the holes (align them with a battery clipped in), and you can use your Makita drill batteries for whatever you want.

Why do you want this? 10.8v batteries will run most 12v things pretty well. I put a power jack on to the end of mine and use it for:

  • 12v air compressors
  • Mains inverter
  • 12v dremel-style drills
  • 12v electric soldering iron
  • Light bulbs (you can get 900 lumen 12v MR16 LED bulbs, which make insanely bright torches)
  • PC fans (to blow air away from work, or to start barbecues)
  • Water pumps (car windscreen washer pumps)

In the pictures I've replaced the dead 9.6v NiCd battery in an old drill of mine with the battery connector, and I can now run run it off Makita Lithium batteries.

Printer:

Sumpod

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Prints straight upwards, without support on a normal 3D printer.

My printer isn't great so you may find the battery is a bit of a sloppy fit if done on a good printer.

description.text:
Why the name? Because of it's heavy girth and material choice.

Since there already exists a million diy 3d printers, I suspect this will mostly be for posterity. (included the original 123D design file)

I've made a 3D printer design which you could build yourself, if you have a smaller hobby cnc, like the Chinese 3040 - 320W models on ebay. Or rather, exactly like that one.

From the first print it already exceeded what my MOD-T can perform, and it eliminates all of the layershifting aswell. All while also printing at twice the speed.

Build Area height is poorly optimized, trying to stay around 30cm max cnc cut length, my cnc is slightly modified and takes a bit of work to get the full travel. (lazy)

It's, XYZ, 185x300x156'ish

22mm MDF for the frame
12mm MDF for the bed
16mm threaded rod
12mm rails all around
2mm pitch leadscrews

59Ncm Nema 17's for the X and Y-Axis
65Ncm Nema 17's for the Z-Axis.

Huge shoutout to https://www.youtube.com/user/ThomasSanladerer his channel is the best resource for people looking to build thier own printer, or just figure out how to optimize thier own. Building it is one thing, making it print is an equal if not greater amount of work.

Some quick improvements I can think of, would be to:
Integrate the endstops into the Z-axis blocks
Aluminium support under the bed.
Integrate an auto level sensor
Smaller pulleys for the X and Y axis, 35T is too big, but I already had the 35T model

Printer:

MOD-T

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

Depends

Notes:

Everything was printed at 0.2 layer height with a 0.4mm nozzle

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

An easy to slide on, easy to slide off clip for your chips to keep them fresh.

This design has quickly become my favorite chip clip. Other clips require you to open a clamp, while this design has no movable parts.

There are 2 versions of this file included. One has an A to show what a monogrammed version looks like. The other is a blank canvas for you to edit as you like with your own initials.

Unsticking the arm

Because this print is so tight, you may find that the arm of your clip has connected to the circle of the clip. To fix this you will need some kind of hard flat object (I use a chisel). Just stick that object into the crack between the arm and the circle and twist. It should pop open fairly easily.

title: Tablet Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I needed a means of holding a 7" Android tablet in the shop where I could see and interact with it while using a milling machine. (The tablet displays readouts from the milling machine.) This holder serves this function nicely.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.200mm

Infill:

20% Cubic

Notes:

Two "Tablet Holders" and one each of the braces will need to be printed.
To assemble, 8 #6-32 x3/8" button head screws and 8 #6-32 nuts are needed. I also mounted rubber feet to the bottom to reduce the tendancy to slide will interacting with the tablet,

The design was laid down in 2D and then extruded to 3D. Screw holes and nut pockets added after extrusion.

Design tool was TurboCAD 21.

title: Nerf MEGA Explosive Tips - Party Snap Foam Dart Tips
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
For some added MEGA explosive fun during your next Nerf War, I've made a 3D printable replacement tip for foam MEGA darts that holds "party snaps" that explode on impact!

The tips are printed in three pieces: the tip, the screw mount, and the head that holds the "party snaps". All three pieces are supplied as individual STLs, so you only need to print what you need for replacement components. I've tested the darts up to 35 feet away from a smooth surface (garage door) and they still explode on impact. I haven't had a single jam as the tip fits perfectly with the foam dart.

There are STLs for both the solid head as well as the head with holes. I highly recommend only printing the aerated head as they are much louder and fall at impact instead of bouncing back 6-12 feet.

Print time @ 0.2mm: 20 minutes per set

Disclaimer: DO NOT SHOOT THESE AT PEOPLE OR ANIMALS

The STL for the standard Nerf Dart explosive tips is available at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2148142

For instructions and testing results, please view the video at: https://youtu.be/ybZklpjmO1I

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

No

0.2mm

20%

Notes:

Layer Height: 0.2mm
Wall Width: 0.4mm
Wall Count: 3
Top/Bottom Layers: 6
Infill: 20%

Carefully remove the tip from a MEGA Nerf bullet/foam dart (the glue they use is very easy to pry away). Drop the tip into the head, add 2-3 "party snaps", screw on the mounting screw, screw the explosive Nerf tip into the foam dart, load your gun, and ENJOY!

Check the YouTube video for more instructions and the testing results of the MEGA dart poppers!

title: Replicator Extruder Wire Bundle Strain Relief Upgrade

description.text:
This is the first thing I've designed. It's a strain relief upgrade for my Makerbot Replicator I made using Autodesk 123D Beta.
The Replicator shipped with a fairly fragile method of tethering the main wire to the extruder carriage and I found that I would have to frequently reattach it (it was a zip tie pulled over a screw head).
Fed up with this design I made a clip which is held in place by the same screw which held the zip tie in place. I took special care to ensure that the screw remains in the same place as it did with the old strain relief solution.
As soon as I get the chance I'm going to be adding a small channel to let the wires come out of the clip at the bottom so that it isn't pinching them as much when it's all screwed together.

Print out the piece, cut the zip tie holding the wire bundle to the carriage and remove the plastic shim on the screw.
Remove the screw from the assembly and carefully push the wire through the clip. I intentionally made the clearance small so it doesn't pop out during operation.
Put the screw through the eyelet and screw it back into the carriage.
Marvel at how secure it all feels :)
I printed mine using 0.3mm layer height, 0% infill and 2 extra shells for rigidity.

comments.text: I had a problem with the file (using makerware, I don't know why) and would not print one of the legs properly. Using Meshmixer's analytics, there was a hole or two one the bottom of the right leg that was easily taken care of (using the analyze menut). I also used meshmixers layout to get an optimized position (though I did rotate it to a final 45 degrees so it would face "up" to eliminate the need for support thus eliminating any need to clear out support material. Sending it back as an stl to Makerware, I then printed it WITH a raft, but NO support, as the Meshmixer file is complete with better support. Lot's of people have been looking for a way to smooth and gloss PLA. I found that dipping (not vapor bathing) PLA printed objects to be a great method to do it. Just swish it around for perhaps 5 seconds - it's a good rule of thumb from which to experiment further.

armOverlap = 2
armOuterDiameter = 45
height = 4
createLock = 1

This thing was customized to my needs so it might have more space for electronics and holes for switches then it might be neccesary for anyone else.

Mesh on filter backplate is achieved by printing with honeycomb infill at ~40% with few perimeters and no top or bottom layers.

Main body backplate is completly optional and to be just glued in place, same with filter back mesh.

80mm computer fan is just screwed in place using wood screws, they also hold filter box in place so remember to use ones that are long enough (mine are roughly 4cm long).

title: HY-SRF05 Ultrasonic Range Finder Mounting Bracket

description.text:
This is, essentially, the same as the HC-SR04 Ultrasonic Rangefinder Mounting Bracket by Matter153. I widened the connector cut-out to account for 5-pin design of the HY-SRF05 sensor (as opposed to the four pins of the HC-SR04 sensor).

Obviously, Matter153 did all the real design work here and I just made a minor tweak. If you want to send a tip, please send it to Matter153.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.200mm

Infill:

20% Cubic

Notes:

Printer is a Prusa i3 MK2.

Printed in PLA or PETG, it can be printed as is. Printed in ABS, scale it up slightly (I used 101%) to account for shrinkage. I prefer to print this in PETG as it is more flexible and makes it easier to pop the sensors into (and out of) the brackets.

Mount with #6-32 screws.

Matter153 says "If you cut a piece of a foam paper plate to put behind the sensor it helps considerably with vibration if you are using this with a robot." I haven't done this myself, but it sounds like good advice so I am passing it along.

comments.text: Good alteration, hopefully it will make the bracket more useful for more people.

title: Bed Leveling Thumb Nut - TRONXY P802

description.text:
Thumb nuts for bed leveling screws. Made as large as possible to accommodate large hands in tight spaces.

Use M3 hex nut... hex fits snug in PLA

Designed around TronXY P802E... Will probably fit other similar printers

UPDATE: 3/9/2017 - I suggest to anyone going to print these... use ABS or other that can withstand higher temps. I had originally printed these in PLA, after several uses I have noticed that the heat transferred from the the hot bed, through the screw and into the nut has actually melted the PLA slightly. If you only print PLA or other plastics that only require very low temps it may not be an issue. I suspect the melting happened during my attempts to print ABS when the bed temps need to be 100+.

remixed_from.title: YRUDS - best extruder for 3D Printer / Reprap

title: My version of YRUDS bowden extruder for RichRap's 3DR delta

description.text:
My version of YRUDS bowden extruder for RichRap's 3DR delta BOM: Mount:
  • 2x M4 10mm screew
  • 2x M4 hammer nut
  • 2x M4 washer (optional, I did not use them)
    • Idler:
  • 1x 626 bearing (19x6x6mm)
  • 1x M6 25mm screew
  • 2x M6 washer
  • 1x M6 nut
    • Spring mount:
  • spring ID 4mm
  • 1x M4 screew (I used 44mm long, you should use good one for your spring)
  • 2x M4 washer (to secure ends of spring)
  • 1x M4 washer
  • 1x M4 nut
    • Stepper mount:
  • 3x M3 x 13mm screews
  • 3x M3 washers
    • Hobbed bolt:
  • hobbed bolt for YRUDS
    http://mojreprap.pl/index.php?route=product/product&path=42&product_id=165
    • 2x 686 bearing (13x6x5mm)
    • some M6 washers to align bolt and gear (I used 4 small and 1 big)
    • Big gear:
  • my version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213808
  • 1x M3 nut
  • 1x M3 screew, I used M3 x 8mm socket headless screew
    • Small gear:
  • 15 tooth HTD 3M
  • 1x M3 screew, I used M3 x 5mm socket headless screew
    • Belt:
  • 195mm (65 tooth) HTD 3M 5mm wide
    http://shop.polybelt.com/195-3M-05-Rubber-Timing-Belt-65-Tooth-B195-3M-05BNG.htm
    • Pipe connector:
  • for OD 6mm ID 4mm pipe (I have connectors with 13mm OD thread)

comments.text: Little update :)

author: Benvan

description.text:
I have been using my FireFly for over a year now. I print a lot of different filament types and change filament often. I wanted an extruder that made changing filament easy, printed all filaments, and did not plug up or skip. This extruder loads filament with just a twist of a big easy knob (see video). It prints any filament that I have tried including flexible. It cleans itself as it prints with a reverse action rotating brush eliminating clogs and skips. It is light weight with a nema 14 stepper and powerful with it's drive gears.

This is an advanced project with many parts, requiring a well calibrated printer to produce some of the parts. If the worm gears don't turn smoothly for you, ask a friend to print them. They don't take a lot of filament.

The "foot" of the extruder is interchangeable with a standard Wade's extruder, so you can probably drop it right on to your X-carriage. I have both 1.75 and 3mm models designed for hexagon and e3d type hot ends. If you would like to test it with a different hot end connection, message me. I would love to facilitate that.

The FireFly extruder
• Is printable
• Handles a wide variety of filament (including flexible) with ease
• Has a very short feed to hotend path
• Uses worm drive for powerful feed in a very small space
• Is super lightweight and agile
• Automatic cleaning
• Uses a smaller and lighter weight stepper motor
• Makes loading filament easy
• The idler can easily be fully opened

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g4EEMcYvLJg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CLjeGuR-7DM
https://youtu.be/khTIw_aLQxE

comments.text:
This is a great-looking extruder. I am working on modifying it to use a DC motor with a worm gear and an optical encoder. This will allow a servo-driven direct drive extruder that is very light weight. However, I have a few questions:
1 - Did you happen to make this using OpenSCAD? Do you have the source files for modification?
2 - What about an e3d clamp and a Prusa carriage mount? Adding lots of adapters and such adds weight and bulk and works against the nice features of this extruder.
3 - Can we make a worm gear with configurable inside diameter? The DC motor may have a much smaller shaft...
If I can get some additional files, I will try my hand at making a nicely adapted version of this.
Thanks!
comments.author: slipton

comments.text: I designed this using Solid Edge.  I can save to many formats, but not SCAD.  If you have some simple changes like the diameter of the drive gear and the mount holes for the motor I can kick those out for you pretty easily.  I would be interested to hear if there is a way to translate this to OpenSCAD.
comments.author: slipton

comments.text:
The changes I want to make are:
1 - Make this compatible with a Prusa i3-style X carriage instead of a Wade mount.
2 - Make this able to take an E3Dv6 hot end. EDIT: I see you've done this already. I suppose it requires some extra clamp and hardware though...
3 - This one is not widely useful - Make this take a cylindrical DC motor instead of a NEMA 17 motor.
comments.author: systemslave

comments.text: I would also be interested in printing a new worm drive that will fit on a 2mm diameter shaft. Can you supply the method that you used to create these worm gears? What are the gear specifications of the worm gear set? Pressure angle, helix angle, circular pitch etc?

comments.text: damn bro. you spent quite a long time on this! good job! i cant wait to try it on my mk2
comments.author: Grooperdude

comments.text: Thank you.  I spent about a year on development.  Let me know when you are ready to try the build and I will send you the parts list for bolts, springs, bearings, etc.  I also have main body models with breakaway printer supports.  Try the worm screw model first.  It is the hardest print and should only take about 20 minutes.  It needs to come out smooth.  I print that part in ABS at 240 with a part cooling fan running.  I seldom print ABS with a part cooling fan due to warping, but the long repeated overhangs and small footprint of this part benefit by it.
comments.author: Grooperdude

comments.text:
What are the advantages compared to a direct extruder using the same motor ? Smaller motor with regular gears ?
Sorry to disappoint you but others, myself included have already looked at worm gear for this usage. I did it and with good gears made of brass and nylon. Far smaller, lighter, simpler than this, yet, my conclusion was: not worth it. A far better extruder can be made with regular gears.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: You are more than welcome to prefer standard gears.  I guess that you have to try the firefly to appreciate it.  It loads filament extremely fast and easy.  It prints stiff and flexible filaments equally well.  It brushes out the feed as it runs.  That makes a huge difference with brittle filaments like PLA.  A standard Wades design uses a nema 17 motor.  The lighter weight nema 14 has less mass and that translates to print quality.  It isn't just the gears.  It is the design.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
As I said, I made a far better design, lighter, faster, stronger, easier to load/unload, all filaments, 280°C etc... with regular gears. Printed gears are no way as good as brass/nylon standard gears and a printed worm gear is even worse.
What is the total mass of your X carriage. All of it, not just the extruder. Why people never gives figures, measures ... BTW ? Mine is 270g

print_settings.Notes:: This is near a hotend so consider printing it in ABS.

description.text:
I spent days looking for a fan shroud that would not blow on my hotend but which would provide a cooling air flow. There were lots of fan mounts, but they were all designed to fit some extruder or other. I had a uniquie situation, and I just could not find a fan mount to fit. I grabbed a couple, made clips and they didn't work for one reason or another.

One of them was a parametric openSCAD ring funnel that was not parametric enough. I fixed a couple bugs in that code, learned a little openSCAD. And I could never find the right cooling fan mount for me. I grabbed a couple rings and mounted one on a special clip, and it burned up, just too big I printed another and could not figure out how to mount it. I wasted days at this, just to get cooling air, and there was no solution I could find and use. There were solutions I could find but not use and there might be solutions I could not find.

I went through pages and pages of fan mounts and other random stuff that came up when you do that search.

I finally decided to do it myself.

I mean for every single thing about this fan mount to be parametric and to be adjustable and, so far as possible, for the rest of the fan mount to "adjust" as you make a change - you change one part of the cone and the rest moves around it. You change the fan mount and the cone changes, and so forth.

The cone is designed in two pieces, what I think of as the concentrator and what I think of as the snoot. The opening can be angled, whether in the snoot or, if the snoot is left off by giving it a length of zero, in the concentrator. There is a single mounting tab defined that extends up from the fan mount a parametric amount. The height of the tab can be controlled, as can the width of the tab, the angle of the mounting tab that extends from the main tab, the slot size and so forth. The tab can be straight, angled, or whatever you like. The fan mount can also be angled acutely or obtusely and so forth. You can make the trapezoidal mount of the tab twist or move side to side. You can make small adjustments if you do something I don't calculate right.

There are STL files included in the print, but that file is just meant to be samples to show you generalities - unless you are very lucky, printing that fan is likely to be useless. To use this, grab a copy of openSCAD. Do some measurements. Figure out your fan size. Plug those numbers into the parametric section. Do previews, play around. When you are done, then you can do a complete rendering and a trial fitting. Plan on as many trial fittings as you think you need, based on your pickiness and desires. Enjoy.

I have probably printed 20 of these fan shrouds to make sure that everyrhing works.

I hope that someone else who is in my position can use this and save themselves some time. Maybe one of the artists whose creations I love and can't duplicate. Enjoy.

This is the third version of the SCAD I have uploaded. In this version I properly put the tab onto the trapezoid so that I no longer need to have a fudge factor. I also added tab twist, and the ability of the trapezoid to lean left or right so that it can duplicate some of the mounts I have seen online. Unfortunately, this now means it is possible to create a disjointed mount where the tab is a separate piece but there are adjustments to move the tab back onto the trapezoid.

Printer:

Any printer should do

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 layers, 0.4 nozzle

Infill:

Does not matter

Notes:

The fan shroud is so thin that infill may not matter (unless you make it thick - and if you need to do that, then you can judge your own infill. I print it on the back - on the opening of the fan and there should be no supports needed - but if you use an angle greater than 90 degrees to angle the fan tab backwards then flipping it over on the funnel bottom might be appropriate, and that might need support.

This is near a hotend so consider printing it in ABS.
Once printed, attach your fan to it and mount it to your extruder. I have not had to do any trimming or scraping.

openSCAD

Unlike most 3D design languages, openSCAD is a programming language that has an Algol or C like syntax. If you are a coder, you will probably easily adapt to the methodology. You can create an object and then add to it or subtract from it to build your final thing. I created the object piece by piece and did a lot of previewing and some slicing and rendering.

Edit 1: There was a step on the inside of the funnel when the transition happened from the first part of the funnel to the second part. I had used a fixed factor and realized that there was a better way - since I finally tried to understand why the walls were thinning.

I am using the average thinning of the horizontal and vertical walls. If this is not acceptable I will do a custom polygon - but then I lose the smoothing of the built-in function. Sigh. I can't think of any combination that would work.

Unfortunately, there is a third way. I am working to see if this is "good enough" and if not I will do the extra work.

Edit 2: The tab is now properly positioned on the trapezoid so long as it is not twisted to the side and there are parameters to adjust the position of the tab in that case. The trapezoid can be leaned to the side and the tab should generally move with it.

Edit 3: If a tab was offset such that the tab leaned past the left edge of the funnel and fan mount, the item might not have a flat back that could be printed on. The "clipping cube" was made larger and offset in the -x direction to cover this possibility.

print_settings.Notes:: Print "Base.stl" with supports.  Unless you know "Ant Man" personally, do not print "Cylinder Piston 484mm.stl" with supports as the valve body portion of this part cannot be cleaned once printed.

title: Single Cylinder Air Engine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Single Cylinder Air Engine runs on compressed air, a vacuum cleaner, a balloon, or even lung power. I've included three adapters in the design to interface with each.

The design incorporates two ports, one upper and one lower. When Single Cylinder Air Engine is viewed from the port side, "Wheel Piston.stl" rotates clockwise when pressure is applied to the upper port, and counter clockwise when a vacuum is applied to the upper port. As pressure or vacuum is applied to the upper port, the lower port functions as an exhaust (when pressure is applied) or an intake (when vacuum is applied). The opposite occurs when the lower port is used for pressure or vacuum.

Video of prototype on balloon power is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r-ZsHjWmFu4.

Video of prototype on vacuum cleaner power in slow motion is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BCS_2vPoIsQ.

Video of a friction test is here (your engine should pass this test before running on balloon power): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=043w3XoWwls. Note how the weight of the piston and piston rod easily return the piston wheel, piston arm, piston rod and piston to the base side pressure stroke.

I probably forgot a file or two or something, so if you have any questions, please feel free to ask.

Designed using Fusion 360, sliced using Cura 2.3.1, and printed in PLA on an Ultimaker 3 Extended.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3 Extended

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

To minimize build plate oozing (and filing), you may try printing the parts on a raft.

Print "Base.stl" with supports. Unless you know "Ant Man" personally, do not print "Cylinder Piston 484mm.stl" with supports as the valve body portion of this part cannot be cleaned once printed.

Prior to assembly, test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding may be required.

Carefully file all edges that contacted the build plate to make absolutely sure that all build plate "ooze" is removed and that all edges are smooth. I used a flat jewelers file and plenty of patience.

Study "Assembly.stl" and "Assembly Exploded.stl", carefully noting the locations and positions of the various components as assembly proceeds.

I assembled the Single Cylinder Air Engine in the following order:

1) Slide "Rod Piston.stl" into position in "Base.stl".

2) Press "Piston 484mm.stl" onto "Rod Piston.stl", exactly 38mm from the end. This must be a very tight fit.

3) Slide "Valve.stl" into "Cylinder Piston 484mm.stl".

4) Press the cylinder assembly into "Base.stl". At this time, the piston rod and valve should easily slide in and out of the "Cylinder Piston 484mm.stl". If not, it's filing time again. Do not overfile as the holes for "Rod Piston.stl" and "Valve.stl" must not be too large in order to minimize air leakage.

5) Position "Wheel Piston.stl" into "Base.stl".

6) Press "Wheel Valve.stl" into "Wheel Piston.stl", carefully noting the relative positioning of the holes in each for "Pin Wheel.stl". At this time, both wheels should spin freely on the base. If not, remove them and sand/file/trim the hole in "Base.stl" and try again.

7) Position "Arm Piston.stl" around "Rod Piston.stl", then press "Pin Arm Piston.stl" into the hole in "Rod Piston.stl".

8) Position "Arm Valve.stl" around "Valve.stl", then press "Pin Arm Valve.stl" into the hole in "Valve.stl".

9) Pivot "Arm Piston.stl" into position over the hole in "Wheel Piston.stl", then press one of "Pin Wheel.stl" into position.

10) Pivot "Arm Valve.stl" into position over the hole in "Wheel Valve.stl", then press the remaining "Pin Wheel.stl" into position.

Once completely assembled, I used the vacuum attachment connected to the lower port and a small shop vacuum to break in the engine. Depending on how well the parts are sanded/filed/trimmed, break in can take anywhere from a few minutes to an hour.

I hope you like it!

description.text:
I printed this over the weekend for my home made Kossel 250 style delta... I had some movement from the bed (+/- 1mm), so I designed the ring that I'll mount underneath the bed which is anchored at three points to the frame.

I use PETG for these parts to withstand heat from the heated bed.

I'm using an FSR system from Ultibots.com... heat was not an issue at 80C, but I can't guarantee how it will work at anything higher.

comments.text: Now I have tried both, with and without the air pump. I think adding air to the system accelerates growth. This is not a scientific observation.

author: quickbike

title: A Fast and Simple Bed Leveling Tool

description.text:
This simple lever can be used to precisely level the bed of a 2-head printer. While designed specifically for the X3Machines' Lorei, it should work with any printer. The needle movement exaggerates the the Z-axis distance under the print nozzle by a factor of more that 20X. With practice, you can level the bed in less that 5 minutes with high accuracy.

Steps for leveling the Lorei:

  1. Make sure the printer is off and cool.
  2. Back all leveling screws fully out so that the bed sits firmly on all 4 rests
  3. Find the highest corner with respect to X-axis arm:
    a: Move the printer head as close to the front-left screw as possible (by moving the bed and/or printer heads)
    b. Lower the head onto the short-side of the lever until the left nozzle is in the lever's groove and the lever pointer is pointing right at the base.
    c. Now without changing the Z-axis height, move the head as close to the 3 remaining leveling screws and observe the lever pointer. The corner where the lever pointer is the highest is your highest corner. You will not adjust this screw.
    d. At the highest corner, adjust the left head height until the lever is pointing even with the base frame.
  4. Move the left print head and lever to the corner opposite the highest along the Y-axis. (For example, if your highest corner was the right-rear, move to the right-front corner.) Use the leveling screw to raise the height of the bed until the pointer is even with its frame.
  5. Now move the right print head and lever to the corner opposite the highest along the X-axis. (For example, if you highest corner was the right-rear, move to the left-rear corner.) Raise the leveling screw until the pointer is even with its frame.
  6. Repeat Step 4 with remaining screw.
  7. Now both nozzles should be equidistant above the bed and horizontal in the Y-axis. Visually inspect and tweak after making a test print.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4B1J2DeTNWv

title: Lufkin 4 in Measuring Wheel - Replacement Wheel

description.text:
I use a Lufkin 4" measuring tape wheel from time to time for my job and recently one of the wheels broke clean off. A couple of measurements, some time in TinkerCAD and then a few hours on the printer and I now have a new wheel.

I choose to split the wheel into two pieces for printing and then connected them via PVC glue. The thought was to eliminate the need for supports so all flat printing was face down. The new wheel is stronger than the old.

I used ABS filament at 20% fill with honeycomb. A couple of strokes with a round file at the hub connecting points and it slid right onto the axle.

author: BurgessG

title: MK8 Extruder Upgrade (Flashforge Creator Dual Extruder)

description.text:
This upgrade places tension against the filament to remove the filament drive gear slippage or skipping that happens when using filament that is not exactly the same diameter.
This upgrade is an adaption of another upgrade on Thingiverse, but is for the Flashforge Creator Dual Extruder, that uses a grooved bearing.

remixed_from.author: ffleurey
remixed_from.title: Direct-drive hinged extruder for E3D/J-Head hot-end (Prusa i3)

title: E3D V6 mount for CTC Prusa i3 Pro B (original mk7 style extruder)

description.text:
A rather minimalistic hot end mount for using an E3D V6 (J-head) hot end on a CTC Prusa i3 Pro B with the original extruder (some Stepstruder mk7-ish clone). It has an extension in the front for attaching an optional radial fan.

This mount will probably work with any similar extruder on any Prusa i3, as the carriage mount scew holes have the standard 30mm spacing. I'm unsure of how exactly the CTC extruder compares to a real mk7 in terms of where the filament hole is though - let me know in the comments if you try it on another extruder!

Screws: all M3. Use 16mm screws to mount the stepper motor, and any screws 20mm or above (+ nuts) to mount the hot end.

(I also guess the "real" E3D V6 has a fitting at the top for a PTFE tube even for the direct drive models. Maybe I'll make an update with an extra STL file that has room for this.)

Donations possible through Paypal: http://paypal.me/soundandvisionunit

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

If you print it in the suggested direction, support will be needed only under areas that don't need a lot of precision. I printed mine with PETG, maybe you will want to reduce the size of the holes (default is 3.35mm holes for m3 screws) if you print with a higher-precision material or printer.

author: dave63021

description.text:
My remix of awesome design created by @ulflindestorm. I've added the hole for fpv camera and removed curved edges.

If you will change the size of plate and wedge you'll probably want to also change the size of fpv camera hole. To do that go to createBase module in openscad and play around with values of sphere radius (though you want to keep them both the same) and x parameter of translate methods.
